overview_of_class: Why do Asian Americans and African Americans seem to be irreconcilable groups? Where can we find evidence of past solidarity and commonality? This course offers an interdisciplinary, chronological, and thematic examination of Asian and Black peoples in the U.S. We will explore the causes of tensions and alliances, through topics such as: the historical overlapping racialization and sexualization of Blacks and Asians; slavery and early immigration legislation; international "Afro-Asian" connections. We then focus on WWII as a turning point for new racial and economic dynamics that separate Blacks and Asians in the post-war economy that led to the myths of the "model minority" and "underclass." We study ideologies that emerged from social movements of the 1960s and 1970s and the results of the Vietnam War to theorize race and identity beyond Black and White to reconceptualize inter-minority relations.
name: Asian/Black Historical Relations in the U.S.
